questions.prompt: In standard form LP, what type of constraints are used?
questions.explanation: Standard form LP has: min c^T x s.t. Ax = b, x ≥ 0 (equalities with nonnegativity)

questions.prompt: The simplex algorithm always finds the optimal solution in polynomial time.
questions.explanation: The simplex algorithm has exponential worst-case complexity, though it performs well in practice.

questions.prompt: What is a basic feasible solution (BFS) in linear programming?
options: A vertex of the feasible polytope
A solution in the interior of the feasible region
Any feasible solution to the LP
questions.explanation: A BFS corresponds to a vertex (extreme point) of the feasible polytope and has exactly n-m nonzero variables.

questions.prompt: In the simplex method, the variable entering the basis is chosen based on the most negative _____ cost.
questions.explanation: The entering variable is selected as the one with the most negative reduced cost, indicating the steepest descent direction.

questions.prompt: If an LP has an optimal solution, at least one basic feasible solution is optimal.
questions.explanation: For LPs with bounded optimal solutions, there always exists an optimal BFS at a vertex of the feasible region.

questions.prompt: When using the graphical method for a 2D LP, where is the optimal solution found?
options: On an edge of the feasible region
Always in the interior of the feasible region
At a vertex or along an edge between optimal vertices
At a vertex of the feasible region
questions.explanation: The optimum is at a vertex or, if there are multiple optima, along an edge connecting optimal vertices.

questions.prompt: Degeneracy in linear programming means the LP has no feasible solution.
questions.explanation: Degeneracy occurs when a BFS has more than n-m zero variables, which can cause simplex to cycle but doesn't imply infeasibility.

questions.prompt: What do shadow prices represent in sensitivity analysis?
questions.explanation: Shadow prices (dual variables) represent the rate of change in the optimal objective value per unit increase in a constraint's right-hand side.

questions.prompt: Interior-point methods for LP have what computational complexity?
questions.explanation: Interior-point methods achieve polynomial worst-case complexity, typically O(n³) per iteration, unlike simplex which is exponential.

questions.prompt: The _____ test determines which variable leaves the basis in the simplex algorithm.
questions.explanation: The minimum ratio test ensures feasibility is maintained when pivoting by determining how far we can move along the entering variable's direction.

questions.prompt: Consider max 3x + 2y subject to x + y ≤ 4, 2x + y ≤ 6, x,y ≥ 0. What is the optimal value?
questions.explanation: The optimal solution is at vertex (2,2), giving objective value 3(2) + 2(2) = 10. We can verify this is optimal by checking all vertices.

questions.prompt: If the LP is unbounded, the simplex algorithm will identify this by finding a direction with negative reduced cost and no positive coefficients in the minimum ratio test.
questions.explanation: Unboundedness is detected when an entering variable can increase indefinitely without violating any constraint (all ratios undefined).

questions.prompt: In the simplex tableau, what indicates optimality has been reached?
options: The right-hand side is all positive
All reduced costs are non-negative (for minimization)
questions.explanation: For minimization, optimality is reached when all reduced costs are non-negative, meaning no improving direction exists.

questions.prompt: What is the relationship between the number of pivots in simplex and problem dimensions?
options: Can be exponential in worst case
questions.explanation: While simplex is polynomial on average, pathological cases (e.g., Klee-Minty cube) require exponentially many pivots.

questions.prompt: Bland's rule and _____ rule are anti-cycling strategies that guarantee simplex terminates.
questions.explanation: Both Bland's and lexicographic rules prevent cycling by imposing deterministic tie-breaking rules for entering/leaving variables.
